sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a neutralization reaction
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH), given the balanced chemical equation: HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H2O(l). The enthalpies of formation for NaCl(aq) and H2O(l) are -407.3 kJ/mol and -285.8 kJ/mol, respectively. The specific heat capacity of the solution is 4.18 J/(g*K), and the mass of the resulting solution is 100 g.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

The enthalpies of formation for the products are given as -407.3 kJ/mol for NaCl(aq) and -285.8 kJ/mol for H2O(l). Since HCl(aq) and NaOH(aq) are strong acids and bases, their enthalpies of formation can be assumed to be zero.

ΔH_reaction = [(-407.3 kJ/mol) + (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [0 + 0]
ΔH_reaction = -693.1 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide is -693.1 kJ/mol.
